body:
Hi @pranaysy,

Thank you so much for doing this extensive dive into the LZ function! I've always wanted to do it, but was too lazy for it, so glad you did it :-) Two things:

1) I've also noticed that the Numba version was actually quite slow. Given the results from your test, I think we should switch to a Pure Python implementation only.

2) So I've actually tested the LZ function against a Matlab script, as shown below. However, I've only tested with small sequences, so I probably have missed an error that becomes more apparent when the sequence becomes longer. I also need to make sure that the Matlab script and the Pure Python / Cython implementation are consistent.

https://github.com/raphaelvallat/entropy/blob/3bf3b6e937687e77965ecb5bfdc69e2a0f059363/entropy/tests/test_entropy.py#L72-L103

Thanks again!
Raphael

Hey Raphael!

Thank you for your response :)

I could take a quick glance and you were right in pointing out in (2) that the MATLAB script and the Python/Cython versions need to be consistent. I decided to check that out.

I went through Quang Thai's MATLAB implementation you'd linked to - thanks a lot for that. He talks about two distinct LZ decompositions - exhaustive and primitive, which then led me to the original 1976 IEEE paper.

---
Using the example from the paper (Section III and Lemma 6 of Section IV)
```
    S = [0,0,0,1,1,0,1,0,0,1,0,0,0,1,0,1]
```
    
**The MATLAB version, _exhaustive_ variant**, returns LZ complexity of 6, the substrings look like this:
```
    0, 001, 10, 100, 1000, 101
```
This agrees with the paper:
 > ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8765418/106452407-d7f1cd00-64ad-11eb-9498-ba833cff0fba.png)
    

**The MATLAB version, _primitive_ variant**, returns LZ complexity of 9, the substrings look like this:
```
    0, 001, 10, 10, 0, 10, 00, 10, 1   # 5 unique
```
This too agrees with the paper:
 > ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8765418/106452468-ee982400-64ad-11eb-8de1-9d970bb334c6.png)
    
**Your Numba version** returns LZ complexity of 6, in agreement with the exhaustive variant. I haven't yet modified the code to return substrings

**Naereen's version**, interestingly -  returns LZ complexity of 7 with different substrings:
```
    0, 00, 1, 10, 100, 1000, 101
```
This is **clearly inconsistent** with either variant from the reference paper - I'd argue that it is sufficient evidence against its correctness (?)

---

Further, I could try estimation with some 20-25 long-ish sequences manually across implementations, and _your Numba version appears to be in agreement with the exhaustive LZ complexity from the MATLAB variant._ Naereen's version almost always returned higher estimates, although they were smaller than the primitive variant - likely due to non-unique elements in the latter. 

Estimates appear to follow this relation:
 ```
    Numba == MATLAB (exhaustive) < Python/Cython (Naereen) < MATLAB (primitive)
```
  
---

This is preliminary, not really rigorous. I am yet to do a more comprehensive analysis, but _we should stick with your current implementation for correctness_. I think some speed-ups are possible, and can definitely address (1). I'll try to work on both - analysis for correctness as well as performance. 

Let me know what you think :)

Best,
Pranay

Hi @pranaysy,

This is really fantastic, well done! What is really surprising is that @Naereen has also created [a notebook that describes  several implementations of LZ](https://perso.crans.org/besson/publis/Lempel-Ziv_Complexity.git/Short_study_of_the_Lempel-Ziv_complexity.html#Python-implementation) (Python, Cython and Numba), and it seems like they are all consistent with Matlab / Entropy (i.e. they return 6).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25703792/106531382-f69e9680-64a2-11eb-9ebc-661cbceb12b8.png)

@Naereen sorry to involve you in this discussion, but is there a reason why the notebooks and Python package are inconsistent? Having your feedback would be very valuable to understand what is the ground-truth for this function.

Thanks to both of you,
Raphael

Hey @raphaelvallat 

Thanks!
Yes you're right, it seems that @Naereen's implementation underwent a change in commit [`5537546`](https://github.com/Naereen/Lempel-Ziv_Complexity/commit/5537546dfcba37dae1079aeb8f8b57d68171ee7e) in order to fix a similar [issue that was raised](https://github.com/Naereen/Lempel-Ziv_Complexity/issues/5). These changes were made to both the Python and Cython versions - so the algorithm in the notebooks is no longer the algorithm in the current package, hence the deviation.

Naereen's insights would indeed be highly valuable :)

Best,
Pranay

issue.title: Update the notebook too (and on Naereen/notebooks as well), after 5537546df

repository.name: Lempel-Ziv_Complexity
repository.description: :package: Lempel-Ziv Complexity, fast implementations with :snake: Python (naive, Numba or Cython for speedup), Open-Source (MIT) :+1: →

issue.body:
See this commit 5537546dfcba37dae1079aeb8f8b57d68171ee7e, and [this discussion](https://github.com/raphaelvallat/entropy/issues/14).

- [ ] Update the notebook too, after 5537546df
- [ ] and on Naereen/notebooks as well

body:
Hi @pranaysy and @raphaelvallat,
No problem, thanks for including me and for having tried [my tiny project](https://GitHub.com/Naereen/Lempel-Ziv_Complexity.git/).

@pranaysy is right, someone pointed an error about a year ago (I had forgotten about it), and I fixed it by changing the Python and Cython versions. I hope they both got fixed!
I didn't think about updating the notebook, sorry.

I'll try to do it asap!

Hi @Naereen,

Thank you so much! So sorry to be a bother, but could you give more details on what was wrong with the previous implementation? And why the new implementation gives results that are different from the original paper?

Merci beaucoup :-) 
Raphael

Hi @Naereen and @raphaelvallat,

Thanks for addressing these concerns :)

I ran some benchmarks for LZ complexity estimation based on 5 different implementations:
 1. Naereen's current Cython implementation
 2. Naereen's current Python implementation
 3. Naereen's previous Python implementation (prior to patching issue 5 with commit [`5537546`](https://github.com/Naereen/Lempel-Ziv_Complexity/commit/5537546dfcba37dae1079aeb8f8b57d68171ee7e) that altered estimates)
 4. Raphael's Numba implementation (based on 3 above)
 5. Quang Thai's MATLAB implementation

I sampled randomly generated binary sequences - 1000 each for lengths 100, 1000 and 10000 in MATLAB and ran the above 5 methods. I found that **implementations 3, 4 and 5 gave identical estimates** for all 3000 sequences. 1 and 2 give the same estimates but these were always different from 3/4/5. I've attached the LZC estimates as well as the raw sequences just in case.
 - [lzc_benchmark_sequences.zip](https://github.com/raphaelvallat/entropy/files/5920146/lzc_benchmark_sequences.zip)
 - [lzc_estimates.csv.zip](https://github.com/raphaelvallat/entropy/files/5920153/lzc_estimates.csv.zip)

I think @Naereen's new implementation lead to some [potentially breaking changes](https://github.com/Naereen/Lempel-Ziv_Complexity/issues/5#issuecomment-772676123)? The previous version - which appears to have been used by Raphael, and is also in the notebooks - appears to be correct. 

Hope this helps. Once we agree on correctness, I want to see if something can be done about performance :)

Best,
Pranay
